facts.text: Smt. Vimala (plaintiff) filed suit No. 73 of 1956 in the court of the Subordinate Judge, South Kanara, for decree for possession of lands, buildings, house-sites in Sch. A, movable properties in Sch. B, possession, management and account of properties in Sch. C, and institutions in Sch. D alleged to be private family religious endowments.
Plaintiff's father Shri Dharmasthala Manjayya Heggade died on August 31, 1955, entitling plaintiff to the suit properties, but defendant wrongfully possessed himself of those properties.

Plaintiff valued properties in Schs. C and D under s. 28 of Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 at Rs. 21,000/- and paid court-fee of Rs. 275/-. Lands in Sch. A valued at 30 times assessment, buildings separately.
On June 28, 1956, Subordinate Judge held Rs. 34,577/- court-fee paid by plaintiff adequate on office objection.
On September 9, 1956, defendant filed written statement objecting to valuation and court-fee.
Trial court raised issue on adequacy of court-fee.
On February 13, 1957, defendant applied for Commissioner to value properties; court dismissed and declared fee adequate.
In Revision Petition 272 of 1957 to High Court of Judicature at Bangalore, HC set aside order, directed trial court to ascertain value, appoint Commissioner if needed, decide afresh.
Subordinate Judge appointed Commissioner, who submitted report; defendant objected, further and supplemental reports submitted.

Subordinate Judge held Sch. D properties ex-commercial, fixed court-fee for possession; Sch. D trust properties, s.28 applied as rival trustees dispute; houses on revenue lands at market value or 30 times assessment; Sch. A lands Rs. 7,74,665/-, house-sites Rs. 27,625/-. Plaintiff paid additional fee.

Plaintiff and defendant filed separate revision petitions to High Court of Mysore; HC heard Advocate-General, confirmed Subordinate Judge except for Nelliyadi Beedu, directed trial court to determine if ex-commercial after evidence.
Defendant preferred appeal to Supreme Court by special leave under Art. 136 against High Court order in Civil Revision Petition No. 1098 of 1959.

legal_issues.text: Whether the defendant has a right to invoke the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court under s.115 CPC against an order determining the adequacy of court-fee paid by the plaintiff on the plaint.
Whether s.12(2) of Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 invests the defendant with a right to move the High Court in revision on court-fee adequacy.

petitioner_arguments.text: By Act 14 of 1955 (Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act), defendant invested with right not only to contest in trial court adequacy of court-fee but also to move High Court in revision if order contrary to his submission passed.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.12(2) of Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955

court_reasoning.text: Court-fees Act enacted to collect revenue for State, not to arm contesting party with weapon to obstruct trial. Question of adequate court-fee primarily between plaintiff and State; defendant has no grievance to invoke revision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defendant may contest valuation in trial court but has no right to move superior court by appeal or revision against order on court-fee.

court_reasoning.text: s.115 CPC revisional jurisdiction conditioned by cls. (a) to (c); no refusal/assumption of jurisdiction or illegality by trial court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defendant honestly believing inadequate fee paid still has no right to revision.

court_reasoning.text: s.12(2) only enables defendant to raise contention on court-fee to assist court; no provision enables defendant to move HC in revision. s.19 allows enquiry/commission but does not arm defendant to obstruct suit via revision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on court-fee at instance of defendant.

holdings.text: Defendant has no right to move High Court in revision against trial court's order adjudging court-fee payable on plaint.
s.12(2) of Madras Court-fees Act does not confer such revisional right on defendant.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 (Act 14 of 1955)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs valuation and court-fee on plaint; enables defendant to plead insufficiency but does not allow revision to HC.

statutes_cited.name: Court-fees Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Enacted to collect revenue for State, not for defendant to obstruct trial.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Limits High Court's revisional jurisdiction; not invocable by defendant on court-fee adequacy.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for special leave appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held that the High Court erred in entertaining the defendant's revision petition on the question of adequacy of court-fee paid by the plaintiff, as such matters are primarily between the plaintiff and the State, and the defendant has no locus standi to seek revision under s.115 CPC.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside implicitly by criticizing error in entertaining revision.

key_quotes.text: The Court-fees Act was enacted to collect revenue for the benefit of the State and not to arm a contesting party with a weapon of defence to obstruct the trial of an action.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle distinguishing purpose of court-fee legislation.

key_quotes.text: Whether proper court-fee is paid on a plaint is primarily a question between the plaintiff and the State.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes lack of defendant's locus standi.

key_quotes.text: The High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defendant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct holding against High Court's action.
